Encyclopedia of the Dog

An annotated edition of Sasha Sokolov's Between Dog and Wolf

18. The Note, Sent in a Separate Bottle / Записка, посланная отдельной бутылкой

by Sasha Sokolov

Translated by Alexander Boguslawski

Note XXXVII

Post Scriptum

  • Woe is us; this clime’s bad for health and the mood,
  • Every day chains of clouds just get denser,
  • The one who later will find these Notes should
  • Burn and scatter on the Wind Rose my verses.
  • Like the Mongol Horde’s treasure, its crown in old tales,
  • Amztarakhan once vanished, passed on,
  • And like roaches that fed in the Khan’s ponytails
  • With time passing, would also be gone;
  • Like during the thaw, tracks of sleighs and of elks
  • Melt and leave no marks to observe;
  • Like—without a trace also—did vanish the works
  • Of nations and the nations themselves;
  • Like after a bottle, despair may be banished
  • Though at first our souls wrings and smotes,
  • The same way—seeking no glory—may vanish,
  • Together with the bottle, these Notes.
  • But who needs this stuff? Therein lies the rub.
  • Why did I, the hunter-ragpicker,
  • On the face of existence a blemish, a scab,
  • A lecher, and a pimp who loves liquor,
  • Compose all these Notes at this river’s spring
  • And floated them down in a hurry?
  • Such a meaningless loss of candles and ink
  • And a waste of the force of the current.
  • How annoying: All these years irretrievably lost,
  • Playing, singing, and having much fun;
  • You gaze in the tumbler—and you’re just a ghost.
  • Alas, things look bad, you are done.
  • Now I darn my old sack during pre-winter’s spell,
  • Fix the fishnets, and sharpen tools’ tines,
  • But I know—pushy buds will stealthily swell

  • And burst out from their narrow confines.

  • So I dare you to burn, you dumb-as-a-bell,
  • My amazing, ingenious lines!

Записка XXXVII

Post Scriptum

  • Увы нам, наш климат для нас нездоров,
  • Тут тянутся тучи цепочкой.
  • Нашедший Записки, на розе ветров
  • Сожги и развей мои строчки.
  • Как сгинула некогда Амзтарахан,
  • Татарской оравы столица;
  • Как вымрет когда-нибудь таракан,
  • Что пасся у хана в косицах;
  • Как в сильную оттепель тают следы
  • Полозьев и лосей наброды;
  • Как — столь же бесследно — пропали труды
  • Народов и сами народы;
  • Как после бутылки минует тоска,
  • Нам душу шершаво потискав, —
  • Так — столь же бесславно — исчезнут пускай
  • С чекушкою вместе Записки.
  • Кому это нужно все — вот в чем вопрос,
  • Зачем я, охотник-лохмотник,
  • На лоне бытья заскорузлый нарост,
  • Срамник, выпивоха и сводник,
  • Записки в верховьях реки сочинил
  • И сплавил в низовья куда-то.
  • Напрасная трата свечей и чернил
  • И силы теченья растрата.
  • Какая досада: лета напролет
  • Гуляешь, коля́дуешь лишку;
  • Посмотришься в кружку — а ты уж удод.
  • Хреново, худые делишки.
  • Предзимье застало за штопкой мешка,
  • Починкой мережи и бочки,
  • Но знаю — набухнут исподтишка

  • И лопнут настырные почки!

  • Попробуй пожги только, дурья башка,
  • Мои гениальные строчки.

Chapter Notes

18

Despite its many oddities, Between Dog and Wolf features a strict, formal structure: eight prose chapters from the perspective of the itinerant grinder Ilya Zynzyrella; five prose chapters that concern the life and thoughts of the dog-keeper Yakov Palamakhterov; four chapters consisting of 36 poems written by Yakov; and a final chapter made up of a single, separate poem, again authored by Yakov. As Alexander Boguslawski writes, the chapters follow this pattern: ABCABACABACABACBAC (“How Sokolov’s” 205). Sergei Orobii suggests that “in the novel Between Dog and Wolf, the principle that will become the cornerstone for determining the root affiliation of Sokolov’s texts of the 2000s is mastered: prose is replaced with ease by poetry, or even merges with it. Such a narrative maneuver, of course, originates not in the plot, but in the field of language: considering that the Russian literary language has ‘worn out’ from constant use and has lost all expressiveness, the writer tries to get away from the usual linguistic norms and constructs a unique style, which becomes the driving force of the narrative. Here, the boundaries between replicas, between direct and indirect speech, between chatter and quotation are fundamentally blurred” (299).

structure
Sent in a Separate Bottle

In Note XXXVI, Yakov claims to send his other 36 poems in a bottle down the river (R273/E216).

intratextuality
18

Despite its many oddities, Between Dog and Wolf features a strict, formal structure: eight prose chapters from the perspective of the itinerant grinder Ilya Zynzyrella; five prose chapters that concern the life and thoughts of the dog-keeper Yakov Palamakhterov; four chapters consisting of 36 poems written by Yakov; and a final chapter made up of a single, separate poem, again authored by Yakov. As Alexander Boguslawski writes, the chapters follow this pattern: ABCABACABACABACBAC (“How Sokolov’s” 205). Sergei Orobii suggests that “in the novel Between Dog and Wolf, the principle that will become the cornerstone for determining the root affiliation of Sokolov’s texts of the 2000s is mastered: prose is replaced with ease by poetry, or even merges with it. Such a narrative maneuver, of course, originates not in the plot, but in the field of language: considering that the Russian literary language has ‘worn out’ from constant use and has lost all expressiveness, the writer tries to get away from the usual linguistic norms and constructs a unique style, which becomes the driving force of the narrative. Here, the boundaries between replicas, between direct and indirect speech, between chatter and quotation are fundamentally blurred” (299).

structure
посланная отдельной бутылкой

In Note XXXVI, Yakov claims to send his other 36 poems in a bottle down the river (R273/E216).

intratextuality

Text Annotations

XXXVII

Boguslawski suggested that the book cointains 37 Notes as an allusion to the year of Pushkin’s death, 1837 (“How Sokolov’s” 207).

intertextuality structure
Post Scriptum

Latin: something written after the main thing.

foreign
Wind Rose

A meteorological tool and predecessor of the compass rose used to show wind speed. It would be worth recalling that Roza Vetrova is one of the main characters and images in Sokolov’s A School for Fools.

explanatory intertextuality self-reference
Amztarakhan

As Ostanin writes, “Amztarakhan (more correct Ashtarakhan, Aztarakan) — the capital of the Astrakhanskii khanate, which arose during the disintegration of the Golden Horde, located not far from the Itil’” (27). According to Boguslawski, “old Tatar names of today’s Astrakhan” (“Annotations” 236).

location Russia explanatory
roaches

Animal motif.

motif
tracks of sleighs and of elks Melt and leave no marks to observe

Prints in the snow.

explanatory
elks

Animal motif.

motif
did vanish the works Of nations and the nations themselves

Like the prints in the snow that fade away, so, too, do the things left behind by peoples and cultures. This is the opposite of Pushkin’s message in his famous 1836 poem “Exegi Monumentum.” Read it in the original and in an English translation here. Indeed, Yakov’s apparent invitation to burn his verses will similarly be reversed at the end of the Note. Sokolov responds: “As a keep Soviet critic would write, Pushkin’s verse is life-affirming, while Sokolov’s, on the contrary, is decadent” (personal communication, August 4, 2023).

explanatory intertextuality
bottle

Alcohol theme.

theme
bottle

Alcohol theme.

theme
Therein lies the rub

A reference to Hamlet’s famous monologue.

intertextuality foreign
liquor

Alcohol theme.

theme
Compose all these Notes at this river’s spring And floated them down in a hurry

So he must have been sailing down the river.

explanatory
You gaze in the tumbler—and you’re just a ghost

In the original, instead of “ghost” (chosen here for the sake of rhyming) we read “udod,” hoopoe. José Vergara writes: “Ilya remains transfigured into this avian symbol of violence, lost family, and longing. Even as he seeks to paint himself as a hero of his own creation, a prophetic Elijah, at the end of the day, Yakov’s poem emphasizes that for Ilya and the other heroes of Sokolov’s novel there is no escaping this identity and his mistakes and traumas. The natural world, through this bird imagery, underscores this view by inscribing these myths upon the characters. Furthermore, the hoopoe image interweaves with Dog’s fixation on alcohol as the revelation of one’s hoopoe identity is found in the reflection inside a tumbler. In vino veritas, indeed.” (“Flap” 366–367). Animal-human motif. Alcohol theme.

translation motif theme
tumbler

Instead of a more common “mirror,” he takes a look at himself reflected on a tumbler. Alcohol theme.

theme
Now I darn my old sack during pre-winter’s spell, Fix the fishnets, and sharpen tools’ tines, But I know—pushy buds will stealthily swell And burst out from their narrow confines.

Kolb reads these lines as follows: “It will not escape the careful reader a/ that the harmless hunters’ activities of mending nets and barrels [in the translation: tines] are followed by a political allusion (hope for a Thaw), and b/ the proximity of the rhyming words bochki [barrels] and strochki [lines]” (212). She suggests that “[a]ccording to the logic of rhyme and to the barrel metaphors,” this part of the poem acts as “a statement of “hope for the publication of the barrel of lines” (212).

explanatory translation
darn

Sewing theme.

theme
pre-winter

Time before winter. A continuation of the temporal setting: autumn shifting into winter (again).

time
buds

Leaf bud. Plant motif. Sokolov explains: “The time of composition of Note 37 is pre-winter, when nature seems to fall asleep. The author is concerned about bad weather, an unhealthy climate. He is saddened by approaching old age and the coming winter, but the finale of the Note is optimistic. The Binger believes that spring will come after winter. The buds of plants will swell and burst, and the foliage will bloom. The mood expressed in these lines is similar to the mood conveyed in the charming poetry of Kozma Prutkov” (personal communication, August 4, 2023). Sokolov mentions in particular the poem “Junker Schmidt.” Read the original and a translation here.

motif intertextuality
Записка XXXVII

Amf4 / Amf3, ABAB.

Амф4 / Амф3. ABAB.

rhyme metrical pattern
XXXVII

Boguslawski suggested that the book cointains 37 Notes as an allusion to the year of Pushkin’s death, 1837 (“How Sokolov’s” 207).

intertextuality structure
Post Scriptum

Latin: something written after the main thing.

foreign
нам, наш климат для нас

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

sound stylistic device
Тут тянутся тучи

Alliteration (tu, t).

Аллитерация (ту, т).

sound stylistic device
розе ветров

Wind rose — a meteorological tool and predecessor of the compass rose used to show wind speed. It would be worth recalling that Roza Vetrova is one of the main characters and images in Sokolov’s A School for Fools.

explanatory self-reference intertextuality
сгинула

Colloquial: to disappear.

register/style
некогда

Literary: once, at some point.

register/style
Амзтарахан

As Ostanin writes, “Amztarakhan (more correct Ashtarakhan, Aztarakan) — the capital of the Astrakhanskii khanate, which arose during the disintegration of the Golden Horde, located not far from the Itil’” (27). According to Boguslawski, “old Tatar names of today’s Astrakhan” (“Annotations” 236).

explanatory Russia location
Амзтарахан, Татарской оравы столица

Alliteration (t, st).

Аллитерация (т, ст).

sound stylistic device
Татарской

A Tatar — a person from Tatarstan (now the Republic of Tatarstan), a speaker of a Tatar language. The Tatar Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic was forcibly established in 1920 and lasted throughout the Soviet period.

Russia location
оравы

Low: horde, gang.

register/style
таракан

Roach. Animal motif.

motif
следы Полозьев и лосей наброды

Prints in the snow.

explanatory
Полозьев

Runners — the pieces of a sled that provide support on either side.

explanatory
лосей

Elk. Animal motif.

motif
пропали труды Народов и сами народы

Like the prints in the snow that fade away, so, too, do the things left behind by peoples and cultures. This is the opposite of Pushkin’s message in his famous 1836 poem “Exegi Monumentum.” Read it in the original and in an English translation here. Indeed, Yakov’s apparent invitation to burn his verses will similarly be reversed at the end of the Note. Sokolov responds: “As a keep Soviet critic would write, Pushkin’s verse is life-affirming, while Sokolov’s, on the contrary, is decadent” (personal communication, August 4, 2023).

Как исчезают отпечатки на снегу, так исчезают и вещи, оставленные народами и культурами. Это противоположное посланию Пушкина в его знаменитом стихотворении 1836 года “Exegi Monumentum”. Можно читать его здесь. Действительно, предпологаемое предложение Якова сжечь свои стихи аналогичным образом будет перевернуто в конце Записки. Соколов комментирует: “Как написал бы заядлый советский критик, этот пушкинский стих жизнеутверждающий, а соколовский наоборот - упаднический” (личная переписка, 4 августа 2023).

explanatory intertextuality
Народов и сами народы

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

sound stylistic device
бутылки

Alcohol theme.

Алкогольная тема.

theme
чекушкою

Colloquial: a small bottle of vodka. Alcohol theme.

theme register/style
вот в чем вопрос

A reference to Hamlet’s famous monologue. Read a Russian translation here.

intertextuality foreign
охотник-лохмотник

Paronomasia.

Парономазия.

sound stylistic device
лохмотник

Dated: in rags.

register/style
заскорузлый нарост, Срамник, выпивоха и сводник

Enumeration.

Перечисление.

rhythm
Срамник

Low: shameless person.

register/style
выпивоха

Low: drunkard. Alcohol theme.

register/style theme
верховьях

The upper section of the river, characterized by the highest gradients and, respectively, the highest velocities of water flow.

explanatory
низовья

Downstream, close to the river mouth. So he must have been sailing down the river.

explanatory
трата свечей и чернил И силы теченья растрата

Paronomasia.

Парономазия.

sound stylistic device
свечей и чернил И силы теченья

Alliteration (s, ch, l, n).

Аллитерация (с, ч, л, н).

sound stylistic device
Гуляешь

Colloquial: to have fun, to relax. The frequent use of the verb gulyat’ is linked to the fact that, in chapter 10, Orina is defined as gulyaschaya: “была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая” (R220/E124). In her case, “гулена” means “party person” and “гулящая” is used to describe a woman with chaotic romantic relationships.

register/style intratextuality
Гуляешь, коля́дуешь лишку

Alliteration (l, sh, k). The unusual accent on the verb not only characterizes the register of the character, but reinforces the metrical pattern.

Аллитерация (л, ш, к). Нестандартное ударение в глаголе не только характеризует регистр героя, но и укрепляет метрическую схему.

sound metrical pattern stylistic device
коля́дуешь

Generally, to go caroling, but here, to revel and drink. Alcohol theme.

theme
лишку

Low: excess, surplus.

register/style
Посмотришься в кружку — а ты уж удод

José Vergara writes: “Ilya remains transfigured into this avian symbol of violence, lost family, and longing. Even as he seeks to paint himself as a hero of his own creation, a prophetic Elijah, at the end of the day, Yakov’s poem emphasizes that for Ilya and the other heroes of Sokolov’s novel there is no escaping this identity and his mistakes and traumas. The natural world, through this bird imagery, underscores this view by inscribing these myths upon the characters. Furthermore, the hoopoe image interweaves with Dog’s fixation on alcohol as the revelation of one’s hoopoe identity is found in the reflection inside a tumbler. In vino veritas, indeed.” (“Flap” 366–367). Animal-human motif. Alcohol theme.

motif theme
кружку

Instead of a more common “mirror,” he takes a look at himself reflected on a mug. Alcohol theme.

theme
удод

Here, Yakov avoids the expected rhyme “урод” (monster, ugly person, deformity). The hoopoe appears several times throughout the novel, mostly in Yakov’s poems (R167, 168, 169, 233, 236, 262, 280/E31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 145, 149, 199). José Vergara writes: “the hoopoe plays a key role in the story of Tereus in Ovid’s Metamorphoses. In this myth, the Thracian king rapes Philomela, his wife Procne’s sister, and cuts out her tongue to keep the secret. After Philomela manages to convey to Procne what happened, the sisters conspire to kill the latter’s son, Itys, and feed him to Tereus. Upon learning of their actions, Tereus in turn seeks them out, but before he can enact his revenge, the gods transform them all into birds: Procne into a swallow, Philomela into a nightingale, Tereus into a hoopoe. According to the folklore, the hoopoe’s hooting call is said to mean “where, where” in Greek – Tereus’s plea as he searches for his displaced family” (“Flap” 364–365). Throughout the novel, Ilya is associated with the hoopoe in that he also looks for his missing family. Therefore, Ilya reenacts this plot as he seeks out Orina and their son, Yakov. “He is displaced, like Tereus, in his various transformations and peregrinations, pursuing his idealized family,” José Vergara writes, “but constantly mired by the imagery he uses and that is used to describe him” (“Flap” 366). Animal-human motif.

intratextuality motif foreign language intertextuality
Хреново

Vulgar: really bad.

register/style
худые делишки

Set expression: худые дела (just no good, all is terrible).

phraseologism
Предзимье

Time before winter. A continuation of the temporal setting: autumn shifting into winter (again).

time
Предзимье застало за штопкой мешка, Починкой мережи и бочки, Но знаю — набухнут исподтишка И лопнут настырные почки

Kolb reads these lines as follows: “It will not escape the careful reader a/ that the harmless hunters’ activities of mending nets and barrels are followed by a political allusion (hope for a Thaw), and b/ the proximity of the rhyming words bochki and strochki” (212). She suggests that “[a]ccording to the logic of rhyme and to the barrel metaphors,” this part of the poem acts as “a statement of “hope for the publication of the barrel of lines” (212).

explanatory
штопкой

Darning. Sewing theme.

theme
мережи

Dialectical: fish net.

register/style
исподтишка

Colloquial: stealthily, on the sly.

register/style
настырные

Low: pushy, aggressive, insolent.

register/style
почки

Leaf bud. Plant motif. Sokolov explains: “The time of composition of Note 37 is pre-winter, when nature seems to fall asleep. The author is concerned about bad weather, an unhealthy climate. He is saddened by approaching old age and the coming winter, but the finale of the Note is optimistic. The Binger believes that spring will come after winter. The buds of plants will swell and burst, and the foliage will bloom. The mood expressed in these lines is similar to the mood conveyed in the charming poetry of Kozma Prutkov” (personal communication, August 4, 2023). Sokolov mentions in particular the poem “Junker Schmidt.” Read the original and a translation here.

Мотив растений. Соколов объясняет: “Время написания Записки 37 - предзимье, когда природа как бы засыпает, автор озабочен плохой погодой, нездоровым климатом, его огорчает грядущая старость и наступающая зима, но финал Записки оптимистичен: Запойный верит, что после зимы придет весна: почки растений набухнут и лопнут, и листва распустится. Настроение, выраженное в этих строчках, сходно с настроением, переданным в очаровательной поэзе Козьмы Пруткова” (личная переписка, 4 августа 2023). Соколов намекает на стихотворение “Юнкер Шмидт”. Можно его читать здесь.

motif intertextuality
дурья башка

Set expression: fool, dumb person.

phraseologism
